title: SB 127
content: The people of California enact the following. The Legislature acknowledges the disproportionate impact of drought on areas heavily reliant on groundwater. While state programs assist communities with water needs, there is no similar assistance for individual homeowners with groundwater wells. The program created by this act aims to provide low-interest loans and grants to individual homeowners for improving drinking water and wastewater treatment. This includes actions like digging deeper wells, addressing water contaminants, and connecting to local water systems. The board will establish a program to offer loans and grants to local agencies and eligible applicants for purposes such as extending service lines, connecting to water systems, and closing abandoned septic tanks and wells for health and safety reasons. The Water and Wastewater Loan and Grant Fund is established in the State Treasury to provide financial assistance for various water-related projects, such as connecting service lines, improving wells, and installing water treatment systems. The board has the authority to adopt regulations to support the program's objectives without following the usual rulemaking process. The Water and Wastewater Loan and Grant Fund is created in the State Treasury for water-related projects. Moneys in the fund can be used by the board upon legislative appropriation. Eligible loan applicants must have a household income below the statewide median, own the residence, lack financial assistance from private lenders, and demonstrate ability to repay the loan. An eligible applicant for a grant from the Water and Wastewater Loan and Grant Fund must have ownership of the residence, be unable to obtain financial assistance from private lenders, demonstrate ability to repay the loan, and meet specific criteria. The loan granted will be secured by a mortgage on the residence, repaid within 20 years with a 1 percent interest rate, and require homeowner's insurance. The board may partner with a private financial institution to provide loans and utilize funds for loan guarantees. An eligible applicant for a grant must have a household income below 60% of the statewide median, own the residence, and be unable to secure financial assistance from private lenders. Recipients must repay the grant if they sell the residence within five years or return any unused funds. $10 million is transferred to the Water and Wastewater Loan and Grant Fund. This act is deemed urgent for public peace, health, or safety. Ten million dollars is transferred from the General Fund to the Water and Wastewater Loan and Grant Fund for providing eligible households with access to safer drinking water and wastewater treatment during California's drought. This act is deemed urgent for public peace, health, or safety. Section 21168.6.7 of the Public Resources Code defines a "water project" funded by the Water Quality, Supply and Infrastructure Improvement Act of 2014. It establishes procedures for legal actions challenging the certification of environmental impact reports or project approvals. The Judicial Council must adopt rules by July 1, 2016, to ensure timely resolution of such actions within 270 days. The draft and final environmental impact report for a water project must include a notice about Section 21168.6.7 of the Public Resources Code, stating that certain comments filed after the public comment period may not be considered. The reports must also include the full text of this section as an appendix. Within 10 days of releasing the draft report, the lead agency must hold an informational workshop for the public. The lead agency must include the full text of Section 21168.6.7 in the environmental impact reports. Within 10 days of releasing the draft report, an informational workshop for the public must be conducted. Additionally, a public hearing must be held before the close of the comment period, and mediation can be requested within five days after the comment period ends. The lead agency must select mediators with expertise in land use and environmental law or science for mediation requested by commenters. The applicant is responsible for the costs of mediation. Agreed upon measures during mediation become conditions of approval. Written comments after the public comment period are only considered if they address new issues raised by the lead agency's response to comments. The lead agency considers written comments after the public comment period only if they address new issues, new information, changes to the project, proposed conditions, or new information not known before. The agency must file a notice within five days after the last project approval. The lead agency must file a notice within five days after the last project approval. The agency is required to prepare and certify the record of proceedings, with the applicant covering all costs. The lead agency must prepare and certify the record of proceedings, with the applicant covering all costs. Within three business days of releasing the draft environmental impact report, the agency must make it and all related documents available to the public in an electronic format. Any additional documents related to the report must be made accessible within five business days. The lead agency must make an index of copyright protected documents available in electronic format by the release of the draft environmental impact report. Written comments on the project should be submitted in electronic format and made public within five days. Non-electronic comments will be converted and made accessible within seven days. Within seven business days, non-electronic comments must be converted to electronic format by the lead agency and made available to the public. The agency shall certify the record of proceedings within five days of filing the notice and provide an electronic copy to parties upon request. A reasonable fee may be charged for the electronic copy. Within 10 days of receiving a complaint or petition, the lead agency must lodge a copy of the certified record with the superior court. Within 10 days of receiving a complaint or petition, the lead agency must lodge a copy of the certified record with the superior court. Any disputes over the record content will be resolved by the court, and relief will not stay construction unless there is an imminent threat to public health and safety. In an action brought under this division, the court may only stay or enjoin the construction or operation of a water project if it poses an imminent threat to public health and safety or if important Native American artifacts or historical values are at risk. If either condition is met, the court can only enjoin specific activities that pose a threat or affect the artifacts or values. The court can only enjoin specific activities of a water project if they pose a threat to public health, safety, or important Native American artifacts or historical values. Any challenge to a project approval must follow specific requirements. No reimbursement is needed for this act as local agencies can cover the mandated costs.
